body: Agree with @mik-laj

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/4949?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [430efc9...d9adf1b](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/airflow/pull/4949?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
Sure, I prefer the doc to be in howto dir with the reason I mentioned above. WDYT @mik-laj @milton0825

@feng-tao Creating file in howto directory is the simplest solution.  Each document can have any structure and does not have to be associated with others in any way. As a last resort, we should create a file in the howto directory if there is no other better place. 

The list of guides in no way allows you to create a documentation structure in any way. The documentation must be structured if it is to be user-friendly. I would like to limit the number of files in the howto directory, because it will not allow to create high-quality documentation in the long-term. 

Currently, work is underway to create a better place for information that the milton0825 user would like to add. 
Reference:
https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/4827

If this change is accepted, we will have one place that will support the developer. The documentation will be able to have a structure. In the future, further documents are planned, which will describe other information for the developer ex. Google Integration Guide
https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/af7637c61acbb877dc68f337b633b2c34a43f91a2ebafc61208daf0c@%3Cdev.airflow.apache.org%3E

We have only one environment described for now, but in the future we will have several environments described and work on the description is ongoing. One place for developer information is needed.
Reference:
https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/4932/files

I point out that the purpose of the documentation is to show how to do something, so the existence of this directory is not a good idea, but it is currently the shortest way to add a new element.  This is a good temporary solution, but it should not be recommended.

Summary: "howto" is a better solution, as a short term solution. It is a place that is much more developer-accessible, but this is a worse solution in a longer period of time. 

CC: @potiuk
It is also worth noting that the information is only for developers. This is not information for the end user. The howto directory describes the information for the end user.

Please prefix your commits with `[AIRFLOW-4008] `

There is some overlap between this PR and #4772 - can you and @galuszkak work out how do get both these in  without duplicating code/what makes sense where etc.
This could probably do with an update in the docs too?
@PaulW Would you be able to add those tests? If you can do it this week we can get this in to the 1.10.3 release

@mik-laj This is your version backported to 1.10. Could you give it a look over please?

@dimberman Added more tests.

Also current test failure is a flake I think; it passed on my branch: https://travis-ci.org/pgagnon/incubator-airflow/builds/508313464
I'm not familiar with Avro/BQ but does this need to be optional? Is there a situation where this changes  or breaks the existing behaviour?

@ashb I've created a new branch on our fork to add these tests & ensure they pass CI tests prior to submitting them, details of which can be seen here:
https://github.com/autotraderuk/airflow/commit/0daa0ec301512a9822935c24a03a6a026c826b77
https://travis-ci.org/autotraderuk/airflow/builds/508337217

We've also done a change around the `_gen_random_string()` function as can be seen here, but unsure whether to also include this as part of the PR or seperate?
https://github.com/autotraderuk/airflow/commit/c124589864405b18d8b863e93c6e23ac601af820
https://travis-ci.org/autotraderuk/airflow/builds/508458801

I think the simplest move here would be to get @galuszkak's PR merged first, and I can just work off the changes that make it into master. It's true that the `PodRequestFactory` was previously entirely untested, so I can see why @galuszkak is reluctant to have that responsibility dumped onto #4772. However, unittesting `PodRequestFactory` is something I've started doing in this PR and could make more comprehensive. If #4772 gets merged I can add the unittests, timeline being ideally before the end of the week. @ashb Would it be possible to get this in before 1.10.3?

Both those changes seem fine to make part of this PR.

Could we also have an explicit non-randomised test too. Something like:

```python
id = "my_dag_id"
self.assertEqual(
    id,
    AirflowKubernetesScheduler._make_safe_label_value(id)
)
id = "my_dag_id_" + "a"*64
self.assertEqual(
    "my_dag_id_" + "a"*49 + "-HASHERE", 
    AirflowKubernetesScheduler._make_safe_label_value(id)
)
```
cc @ashb

So an interesting possible side effect of this: I think  it is causing an exception on the "ad-hoc query" pages in 1.10.

Once the run completes https://travis-ci.org/ashb/airflow/jobs/509535397 I'll  be able to see what's going on. But it might be a problem with all the example connections we create.

May not  be worth cherry-picking this on to 1.10.3

Yup:

```
    airflow/www/views.py line 2188 in query
      ((db.conn_id, db.conn_id) for db in dbs if db.get_hook()))
    airflow/www/views.py line 2188 in <genexpr>
      ((db.conn_id, db.conn_id) for db in dbs if db.get_hook()))
    airflow/models/connection.py line 230 in get_hook
      return AzureDataLakeHook(azure_data_lake_conn_id=self.conn_id)
    airflow/contrib/hooks/azure_data_lake_hook.py line 39 in __init__
      self.connection = self.get_conn()
    airflow/contrib/hooks/azure_data_lake_hook.py line 49 in get_conn
      client_id=conn.login)
    .tox/py27-backend_sqlite-env_docker/lib/python2.7/site-packages/azure/datalake/store/lib.py line 110 in auth
      raise ValueError("tenant_id and client_id must be supplied for authentication")
   ValueError: tenant_id and client_id must be supplied for authentication
```

Trying to think if this will cause any other problems on master code that we haven't though of  with  the sample connections.

Is that not a part of the definition of `cases`?

```    def _cases(self):
        cases = [
            ("my_dag_id", "my-task-id"),
            ("my.dag.id", "my.task.id"),
            ("MYDAGID", "MYTASKID"),
            ("my_dag_id", "my_task_id"),
            ("mydagid" * 200, "my_task_id" * 200)
        ]

        cases.extend([
            (self._gen_random_string(seed, 200), self._gen_random_string(seed, 200))
            for seed in range(100)
        ])

        return cases
```

Specifically `("mydagid" * 200, "my_task_id" * 200)`?
Almost, but it doesn't include what the value _should_ be, just that the code in the tests says "yes it's safe now".

PTAL @feng-tao @Fokko 
Tests passed on: 
https://travis-ci.org/milton0825/airflow/builds/509546989
cc @Fokko @kaxil @ashb
Thank you @Trollgeir . LGTM. Will merge once CI pass (I have re-triggered two failing ones to see if they're transient failure)

is your description correct? 
```The number of backfill tasks should be limited by the pool slots if we specified the
pool to use with:
airflow backfill --pool 
If no pool is specified, the number of backfill tasks per backfill should be limited by non_pooled_backfill_task_slot_count
```

Each backfill Dag run shared the same TI with scheduler DAGRun which should have the pool config, why do we need to provide the pool name for backfill?

@ashb , thanks. BTW, what do you think of moving https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/master/airflow/www/security.py#L35-L140 inside AirflowSecurityManager so that we could redefine permission on different roles by subclassing the security manager?

@mik-laj Add prerequisites,
@XD-DENG PTAL, Thanks.

@milton0825 I think you are assuming backfill is using LocalExecutor which is only for certain use case(like Lyft). But I think there are many other use cases which use the default executor as the scheduler job(celery) which I think using the original task instance pool make senses.

WDYT @milton0825 @ashb @astahlman

@feng-tao even if we are using the same executor as scheduler, I still think we should not use the same task instance pool. It is possible that the user launch a huge backfill that occupies the pool and causes normal tasks to starve. In general, I think we should have better isolation between normal tasks and backfill tasks. I feel like backfill tasks should have their own pool.

> It is possible that the user launch a huge backfill that occupies the pool and causes normal tasks to starve

That is the behaviour I _want_. The reason for having a pool is to limit access to an external API with rate limits. If backfill uses it's "own" pool then you have doubled the capacity of the pool.
Yes that probably makes sense to do.
Thanks, this was my fault from a bad cherry-pick.

So I had  cherry-picked this on to v1-10-stable for inclusion in 1.10.3 but I just had a thought:

Does this change now mean that dags will not show up in the webserver if the scheduler is not running? Are we okay with that behaviour? Do we need to document that somewhere?
This leaves DagRun  objects not being deleted - that doesn't sound like the right fix.
Thanks  @PaulW, I'll get  this in 1.10.3  too!

environment:
```
>>> import boto3
>>> boto3.__version__
'1.9.120'
>>> import urllib3
>>> urllib3.__version__
'1.24.1'
>>> import botocore
>>> botocore.__version__
'1.10.84'
```

I resolved this issue by updating the version of `botocore` to `1.12.120` and `moto` to `1.3.7`.
By the way, after updating `moto` to `1.3.7`, you have to export `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY` and `AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID`  to whatever to avoid `NoCredentialsError`.

Reference: https://github.com/spulec/moto/issues/1924

Hi @ashb @XD-DENG 

PTAL, thanks

Hi @cchung100m , a few suggestions outside the code change scope:
- please provide meaning PR subject so that folks can quickly identify if it's something they can share inputs (I have updated subject of this PR to a meaning one). 
- next time please update your PR details accordingly based on the template, e.g., providing the correct JIRA Link, and provide necessary description.

Thanks again for your PR thought ;-)

@zhongjiajie - Thanks for your comments.  

I generally try to keep conditions separate so that they can log specific messages for easy debugging. I was also using a try block is so that I can log the exception and then propagate it.  But I agree with your feedback and that it makes the code more concise and have made the recommended changes.

I am not sure of what would be an intuitive name for the sqs sensor.  I was thinking that `sensor` will indicate it subscribes to sqs.  But if SQSPushXComSensor/SQSPushSensor or any other name is more expressive, please let me know.

Thanks again for your time and advice.

Yes, this looks good. One minor thing, we need to set the `extract_xcom` to True: https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/cf934be127206d2d75dce49f1fb0b2c2ffcdcb63/airflow/contrib/kubernetes/pod_launcher.py#L43

We should get rid of the above `extract_xcom` parameter, and always return the xcom. The BaseOperator will take care of xcom being enabled, or not: https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/cf934be127206d2d75dce49f1fb0b2c2ffcdcb63/airflow/models/__init__.py#L1397

As a committer on Avro as well, I think I can chip in here. I would say that having BQ to pick up the logical types is a behavior that we would like to use. For example, the physical type of a TIMESTAMP is an int (seconds since epoch), but we would still like to have BQ interpret this a timestamp instead of a plain integer.
